speaker: Apiza
text: you can use the al_wait_for_event(ALLEGRO_EVENT_QUEUE* q, ALLEGRO_EVENT* ev) function to get input from the user

text: al_wait_for_event(ALLEGRO_EVENT_QUEUE* q, ALLEGRO_EVENT* ev) will populate the ALLEGRO_EVENT* object upon success

text: What variables does the ALLEGRO_EVENT* object have?

speaker: Apiza
text: would you like the entire union declaration?

Programmer

text: Sure!

speaker: Apiza
text: ALLEGRO_KEYBOARD_EVENT is a struct that contains a display pointer, the keycode of the physical key pressed, and other information

speaker: Programmer
text: How can I play soudn?

speaker: Programmer
text: How can I play sound?

speaker: Apiza
text: The first step to playing audio is to initialize an audio driver

speaker: Programmer
text: How do I initialize an audio driver?

speaker: Apiza
text:
You can use the function:

bool al_install_audio(void)

to initialize an audio driver

speaker: Programmer
text: What's the next step?

speaker: Apiza
text: The second step to playing audio is to initialize audio codecs

speaker: Programmer
text: How do I initialize audio codecs?

speaker: Apiza
text: You can do this using the function:\n\nbool al_init_acodec_addon(void)

speaker: Programmer
text: What's the next step?

speaker: Apiza
text: There are several branches at this point that a user can take.

speaker: Apiza
text:
What are you attempting to do?

1) Play a pre-recorded sample
2) Play a sample recorded from a microphone

speaker: Programmer
text: Play a pre-recorded sample

speaker: Apiza
text: The first step to playing a sound file is to reserve the sample in memory.

speaker: Apiza
Programmer
text: What is the parameter num_samples

speaker: Apiza
text:
int num_samples in reference to function:

bool al_reserve_samples(int num_samples)

speaker: Apiza
text: refers to the number of sound files you want to load into memory.

speaker: Programmer
text: Okay,

speaker: Programmer
text: what's the next step?

speaker: Apiza
text:
The next step is to play the loaded ALLEGRO_SAMPLE* object using the function:

bool al_play_sample(ALLEGRO_SAMPLE *spl, float gain, float pan, float speed,
 ALLEGRO_PLAYMODE loop, ALLEGRO_SAMPLE_ID *ret_id)

speaker: Programmer
text: Can you explain to me the parameters of that function?

speaker: Apiza
text: Sure!

speaker: Apiza
text: Here is a description of the parameters:\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text:
ALLEGRO_SAMPLE* spl: The sample file data
float gain: The gain of the played sample
float pan: The pan of the played sample
float speed: The speed to play the file
ALLEGRO_PLAYMODE loop: whether to loop the file or not
ALLEGRO_SAMPLE_ID* ret_id: Typically NULL, however this is the return id to be used

speaker: Programmer
text: And you explain more about ALLEGRO_PLAYMODE

speaker: Apiza
text: Here are the options for ALLEGRO_PLAYMODE:\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: Sample and stream playback mode.\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: * ALLEGRO_PLAYMODE_ONCE\n* ALLEGRO_PLAYMODE_LOOP\n* ALLEGRO_PLAYMODE_BIDIR

speaker: Programmer
text: How would I display text?

speaker: Apiza
text: I am sorry,

speaker: Apiza
text: there are multiple ways to show text,

speaker: Apiza
text: specifically to which do you refer?

speaker: Programmer
text: I would like to display a score on the corner of the screen

speaker: Apiza
text: Would you like to draw a font?

speaker: Programmer
text: Yes

speaker: Apiza
text: Great!

speaker: Apiza
text: You can start by initializing fonts.

speaker: Apiza
Programmer
text: Then?

speaker: Apiza
text: Have you created a display?

speaker: Programmer
text: Yes

speaker: Apiza
text: you can first load in a font using the function:\n\nALLEGRO_FONT* al_load_ttf_font(const char* fpath, int size, int flags);

speaker: Programmer
text: Can you elaborate on the flags parameter?

speaker: Apiza
text: Here is flag information:\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text:
The following flags are supported:

* ALLEGRO_TTF_NO_KERNING - Do not use any kerning even if the font file
 supports it.

* ALLEGRO_TTF_MONOCHROME - Load as a monochrome font (which means no
 anti-aliasing of the font is done).

* ALLEGRO_TTF_NO_AUTOHINT - Disable the Auto Hinter which is enabled by default
 in newer versions of FreeType. Since: 5.0.6, 5.1.2

speaker: Programmer
text: Then?

speaker: Apiza
text: You can draw text using the following function:\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: void al_draw_text(const ALLEGRO_FONT *font,\n ALLEGRO_COLOR color, float x, float y, int flags,\n char const *text)

speaker: Programmer
text: Can you give me more information about the color parameter

speaker: Apiza
text: ALLEGRO_COLOR is a struct containing rgba values.

speaker: Apiza
text: Would you like the declaration

speaker: Programmer
text: Yes

speaker: Apiza
Programmer
text: Can you give more more information about the flags parameter?

speaker: Apiza
text:
The `flags` parameter can be 0 or one of the following flags:

- ALLEGRO_ALIGN_LEFT - Draw the text left-aligned (same as 0).
- ALLEGRO_ALIGN_CENTRE - Draw the text centered around the given position.
- ALLEGRO_ALIGN_RIGHT - Draw the text right-aligned to the given position.

speaker: Programmer
text: What is a typical font size for ALLEGRO_FONT

speaker: Apiza
text: It depends on your screen.

speaker: Apiza
text: I would suggest trying a bunch of values. Typically, I would suggest 72

speaker: Programmer
text: How big are the numbers r, g, b, and a typically are for ALLEGRO_COLOR

speaker: Apiza
text: rgb are typically within [0,255].

speaker: Apiza
text: Allegro5 supports utility functions to map rbg values to an ALLEGRO_COLOR struct instance

speaker: Programmer
text: Can you show my the utility functions?

speaker: Apiza
text: One such utility is:\n\nALLEGRO_COLOR al_map_rgb(float r, float g, float b)
